evidence.dc:description: Immunohistochemistry was performed on palmar-skin sections of controls and affected individuals. AQP5 is localizaed to the plasma membrane in the keratinocytes of the stratum granulosum.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Autosomal-dominant diffuse nonepidermolytic palmoplantar keratoderma is characterized by the adoption of a white, spongy appearance of affected areas upon exposure to water. After exome sequencing, missense mutations were identified in AQP5, encoding water-channel protein aquaporin-5 (AQP5). Protein-structure analysis indicates that these AQP5 variants have the potential to elicit an effect on normal channel regulation. Immunofluorescence data reveal the presence of AQP5 at the plasma membrane in the stratum granulosum of both normal and affected palmar epidermis, indicating that the altered AQP5 proteins are trafficked in the normal manner. We demonstrate here a role for AQP5 in the palmoplantar epidermis and propose that the altered AQP5 proteins retain the ability to form open channels in the cell membrane and conduct water.
dc:source.dc:creator: Blaydon DC
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in AQP5, encoding a water-channel protein, cause autosomal-dominant diffuse nonepidermolytic palmoplantar keratoderma.

evidence.rdfs:label: Blaydon 2013 Expression

evidence.dc:description: Aquaporins are cell-membrane proteins that allow osmotic movement of water across the cell membrane. The disease is characterized by white, spongy appearance of affected areas upon exposure to water.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The cDNA for the fifth mammalian aquaporin (AQP5) was isolated from rat, and expression was demonstrated in rat salivary and lacrimal glands, cornea, and lung (Raina, S., Preston, G. M., Guggino, W. B., and Agre, P. (1995) J. Biol. Chem. 270, 1908-1912). Here we report the isolation and characterization of the human AQP5 cDNA and gene. The AQP5 cDNA from a human submaxillary gland library contains a 795-base pair open reading frame encoding a 265-amino acid protein. The deduced amino acid sequences of human and rat AQP5 are 91% identical with 6 substitutions in the 22-amino acid COOH-terminal domain. Expression of human AQP5 in Xenopus oocytes conferred mercurial-sensitive osmotic water permeability (Pf) equivalent to other aquaporins. The human AQP5 structural gene resides within a 7. 4-kilobase SalI-EcoRI fragment with four exons corresponding to amino acids 1-121, 122-176, 177-204, and 205-265 separated by introns of 1.2, 0.5, and 0.9 kilobases. A transcription initiation site was identified 518 base pairs upstream of the initiating methionine. Genomic Southern analysis indicated that AQP5 is a single copy gene which localized to human chromosome 12q13; this coincides with the chromosomal locations of the homologous human genes MIP and AQP2, thus confirming 12q13 as the site of an aquaporin gene cluster. The mouse gene localized to distal chromosome 15. This information may permit molecular characterization of AQP5 expression during normal development and in clinical disorders.
dc:source.dc:creator: Lee MD
dc:source.dc:title: The human Aquaporin-5 gene. Molecular characterization and chromosomal localization.

evidence.rdfs:label: Lee 1996 Biochemical Function

evidence.dc:description: TRPV4 is a calcium-permeable cation channel expressed in epidermis and sweat glands (among other tissues). It interacts with AQP5 to act as an osmosensor that couples osmotic stress to downstream signaling cascades. Activation of TRPV4 by hypotonic solution requires AQP5, so via patch-clamp technique, they found that the basal activity of of TRPV4 is strengthened when coexpressed with wtAQP5 and cells coexpressing the Asn123Tyr mutant showed a further increased basal activity of TRPV4. The HTS-induced current is more robust and rapid in TRPV4/Asn123TyrAQPt cells, suggesting a GOF. The mutant AQP5 may make the channel leaky and/or more sensitive to HTS, resulting in cell swelling under hypotonicity and leading to the aquagenic whitish spongy appearance.

dc:source.dc:creator: Cao X
dc:source.dc:title: Mutation in AQP5, encoding aquaporin 5, causes palmoplantar keratoderma Bothnia type.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cao 2014 Functional Alteration

evidence.dc:description: AQP5 can regulate permeability in airway epithelial cells via microtubule stabilization (PMID: 22715407). When AQP5 was reduced, lower levels of microtubule assembly were seen and decreased permeability. The authors investigated the levels of tubulin acetylation in biopsy samples using IHC to observe total alpha-tubulin and acetylated alpha-tubulin. They saw a slight increase in total alpha-tubulin and a significant increase in acetylated alpha-tubulin compared to the control palm.
evidence.rdfs:label: Blaydon 2013 Functional Alteration

evidence.dc:description: Studied localization of aquaporins in rat and mouse skin and sweat glands. AQP5 resides in plasma membranes of sweat secretory cells and is essential for sweat secretion. AQP5 null mice showed reduction in pilocarpine-induced sweat response. Dysregulation of AQP5 in sweat glands may contribute to hyperhidrosis, which is a feature of the disease.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The distribution and function of aquaporins (AQPs) have not previously been defined in sweat glands. In this study, AQP1, AQP3, and AQP5 mRNA were demonstrated in rat paw by reverse transcription (RT)-PCR, but AQP2 and AQP4 were not. AQP1, AQP3, and AQP5 protein were confirmed in these tissues by immunoblotting. AQP1 was identified in capillary endothelial cells by immunohistochemical labeling, but not in sweat glands or epidermis. Abundant AQP3 expression was seen in basal levels of epidermis, but not in sweat glands. AQP2 and AQP4 were not observed in either skin or sweat glands. Immunohistochemical labeling revealed abundant AQP5 in secretory parts of rat and mouse sweat glands, where immunoelectron microscopy demonstrated abundant AQP5 labeling in the apical plasma membrane. AQP5 immunolabeling of human sweat glands yielded a similar pattern. To establish the role of AQP5 in sweat secretion, we tested the response of adult mice to s.c. injection of pilocarpine, as visualized by reaction of secreted amylase with iodine/starch. The number of active sweat glands was dramatically reduced in AQP5-null (-/-) mice compared with heterozygous (+/-) and wild-type (+/+) mice. We conclude that the presence of AQP5 in plasma membranes of sweat glands is essential for secretion, providing potential insight into mechanisms underlying mammalian thermoregulation, tactile sensitivity, and the pathophysiology of hyperhidrosis.
dc:source.dc:creator: Nejsum LN
dc:source.dc:title: Functional requirement of aquaporin-5 in plasma membranes of sweat glands.

evidence.rdfs:label: Nejsum 2002 Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Does not fully recapitulate since the authors used a null mouse
Structural modeling suggests that replacing Ile45 with the smaller serine might also widen the diameter of the constriction point.

evidence.detectionMethod: Large 3 generation family of Chinese Han ethnicity with PPKB (including 10 affected individuals). All living family members gave blood samples. WES on III-8, III-9, III-14. Sanger sequencing on all other family members.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Slowly progressive thickening of palms and soles since age 3 years. Mild palmoplantar hyperhidrosis, recurrent tinea pedis and onchomycosis caused by dermatophytes infection. Hyperkeratotic plaques on palms and soles and erythrokeraototic plaques on dorsum of hands and feet. Skin maceration and tinea unguium of several nails.
evidence.rdfs:label: Han Family Proband

evidence.dc:description: IHC performed on sections of dosum of proband and control- no difference in expression or distrubution of AQP5. Similar in eccrine sweat glands. Expressed the mutant in HEK293 cells and found the hypotonic solution elicited a quicker and larger increase in cell volume in cells expressing the mutant vs wild type.
Same variant found in other British family- possibility of a founder?

evidence.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis was used to map region. Exome sequencing on proband followed by Sanger sequencing of other family members.
evidence.rdfs:label: III-19

evidence.dc:description: Structural modeling predicts that Ile177 line the extracellular end of the water channel and replacing it with the bulkier Phe may have an effect on the diameter of the channel via steric hindrance.

evidence.detectionMethod: Exome sequencing performed on one individual. Sanger sequencing was used to identify variant in other families.

evidence.dc:description: Arg188 is a key component of the ar/R constriction point in the water channel and is the most highly conserved of all the AQP5 amino acid variants identified in diffuse NEPPK, and the simplest interpretation of substitution by the smaller cysteine is the widening of the channel at its narrowest point.
Structural modeling predicts that the residue, located on the extracellular surface of AQP5, is important for stabilizing the tertiary and quaternary structures of the protein.

This is a Swedish founder variant. It was only given full 0.5 points here- all others were assigned 0.1 point. Structural modeling predicts that the residue, located on the extracellular surface of AQP5, is important for stabilizing the tertiary and quaternary structures of the protein.

evidence.detectionMethod: Large 4 generation family with 14 affected individuals, but only proband and son were genotyped.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Recurrent secondary dermatophyte infections, Diffuse keratoderma of palms and soles, pitted keratolysis and erythematous keratotic plaques on hands and feet. Sparing of the skin in arches of planta pedis.

dc:source.dc:abstract: An autosomal dominant form of diffuse non-epidermolytic palmoplantar keratoderma, palmoplantar keratoderma of Bothnian type, is caused by mutations in the AQP5 gene encoding the cell-membrane water channel protein aquaporin 5 leading to defective epidermal-water-barrier function in the epidermis of the palms and soles.
dc:source.dc:creator: Krøigård AB
dc:source.dc:title: The first Danish family reported with an AQP5 mutation presenting diffuse non-epidermolytic palmoplantar keratoderma of Bothnian type, hyperhidrosis and frequent Corynebacterium infections: a case report.

evidence.rdfs:label: Danish family proband

evidence.dc:description: Found in Swedish family from Blaydon, 2013
